text:
I make a recipe very similar to this.  I do not use lettuce (as it tends to wilt as it sits out) and I don't use green pepper.  Even though I love green pepper, I don't feel it belongs in this recipe (just my opinion). I make homemade guacamole and put that layer on top of the sour cream/cream cheese layer.  I found a good guac recipe on this site (LuvAnn's Guacamole) that I use.  They always "lick the platter clean" every single time.  I've NEVER had leftovers.  I serve with Tostitos Scoops as they grab the dip more!  Oh and this doesnt' totally spread to fit in a 13x9 pan (mostly the beans don't) so I bought a clear pyrex dish a slightly smaller size.  This dish has pretty much become my 7-layer dip dish because it's requested so much at every party!  This is an awesome crowd pleaser.

text:
This recipe is very good as is, but is also easy to alter to personal taste.  I have took suggestions of others and added 1 lb. of hamburger to the taco seasoning and guacamole instead of lettuce, both very good. I however like this recipe best with medium taco seasoning and salsa and also adding a can of Rotel instead of the tomato, green pepper, onions.  Very easy and adds a bit of a kick to it. The 13X9in. dish works the best.

text:
Great dip.  I started off with the beans for layer one.
The cream cheese , sour cream, and half of taco seasoning mix(makes it very spicy)mixed together for layer two.
I added guacamole for layer three.
Diced tomatoes for layer four.
Black olives for layer five.
Salsa for layer six and
lots of shredded cheese for layer seven.
I skipped onions, lettuce, and peppers and spread my layers in a 13x9 inch glass dish and heated at 350 for 30 minutes and talk about people raving.
Everyone wanted to know the recipe.
Easy, delicious and def a keeper for a fun appetizer

text:
Just wonderful!

I actually used a hybrid of user advice here and ended up with this layer combination (from bottom up): Layer 1-refried beans
Layer 2-Cream cheese, sour cream and taco seasoning
Layer 3-Guacamole
Layer 4-Tomatoes, green peppers, green onions, and lettuce
Layer 5-Salsa
Layer 6-Shredded Cheddar cheese
Layer 7-Black beans

I really liked this combination of ingredients and didn't find the lettuce or any of the other vegetables to be bothersome.

I didn't know whether I would prefer this dish hot or cold, so I served it warm the first night, and we had the leftovers cold.  I love it either way, and plan to make it again, both for my own family and for get-togethers, for which it is perfect in terms of size.

text:
I'm a big fan of taco dip, so I LOVED this recipe.  I've made it many times and everyone always loves it.  I think it's way better without meat in it.  I find that I can't have it in the refrigerator, because if I do I'll eat it for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  My only suggestion would be to definitely get the thick and chunky salsa, and drain it a bit; otherwise it gets a little runny.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Any time you combine these ingredients, you are going to get something pretty tasty. But I think this particular recipe has some issues. For instance, why mix cream cheese in with the sour cream? To me, that doesn't seem to add a lot, and it throws the proportions off (too much dairy). I'd rather mix the taco seasonings into the sour cream and forget the cream cheese. Why put the cheddar cheese at the very top instead of on the (presumably hot) refried beans, where it will get a little gooey? And if you're going to add multiple layers that look alike (e.g. diced tomatoes & salsa, or green pepper/green onions/lettuce), why put them together so they only look like one layer? There are better ways to order the layers.

If you make this and put lettuce in it, be sure to chop the lettuce very, very finely; otherwise you can't dip through the lettuce layer with any normal chip.

I'd suggest finding another layer dip, or making modifications to this one. I wouldn't make it again as-is. It's not bad, but given that there are so many great recipes for layer dips out there, I wouldn't settle for one that's just "not bad."

country:
None
text:
My experience with making this dip was that the salsa caused it to get a bit watery and break down the sour cream/cream cheese layer, and the lettuce wilted and became a bit soggy.  Tasted great and guests gobbled it up regardless, but didn't look terribly appealing (I overheard a lot of "what is this?"  and "it's good, just a little messy-looking")...  I solved this problem by combining taco seasoning, refried beans, and salsa for the first layer.  This also ended up bulking up the bean layer, which I thought was a bit thin the first time I made it.  For the sour cream/cream cheese layer, I now substitute sour cream with green onion dip.  Adds a little something extra, I think.  I made guacamole to top the sour cream layer, then topped with chopped tomato (omitted bell peppers, green onions, and lettuce), finely shredded cheddar and sliced black olives.  I will definitely make it this way from now on!  It held together beautifully and the flavors and textures were perfect!

I noticed that a few people commented that they didn't care for the lettuce cause it wilts... try shredded cabbage instead... it's more authentic for mexican style food and it holds up better.  It also provides much more nutritional value as well as more flavor and crunch!  I hardly ever use lettuce in my mexi recipes now!

text:
I took this dip recipe and modified it a bit after reading some of the other reviews, but it really is fantastic and a great hit when I brought it to a Super Bowl party.

I took out the tomato, green pepper, green onions, and olives, and added in guacamole, jalapenos and salsa (it had to be chunky, otherwise the dip will be runny). I layered it in this order (from the bottom up): (1) - Refried beans with the taco seasoning, (2) - Cream cheese and sour cream, (3) - Guacamole, (4) - Lettuce, (5) - Salsa, (6) - Cheddar cheese, (7) - Diced jalapenos. After that, I heated it up, covered, for 30 minutes at 350 degrees. It was absolutely phenomenal.

text:
I made this for a party recently and was told that it was the best 7 layer dip ever!  I did take note of the reviewers who said it tended to be on the watery side, so I picked a chunky style salsa and strained it, and also seeded the tomato. In addition, just for personal preference, I added some of the taco seasoning to the sour cream and cream cheese mix, left out the green pepper and the lettuce, and used black refried beans.  Not watery at all and quite delicious.  Thanks for the great dip, will definitely make this one for a party again.

I ate it all by myself within two days. I mixed the avocado with canned pizza tomatoes which I drained first. The avocado didn't turn brown that way, since tomato has some acid. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This will definitely be one of my go-to party dishes in the future! I made it last Saturday for our Independence Weekend party and it was completely devoured. Multiple people seriously just hung out by the dip so they could eat to their hearts' content. It was really delicious! I used this recipe as a template, but like other reviewers, made some personal changes to fit our tastes. For the first layer, I used 2 cans of fat free refried beans (1 can was just not enough, and nobody seemed to notice a taste difference with the ff beans) mixed with one packet of taco seasoning. The second layer was the sour cream/cream cheese mixture. The third layer was a jar of thick n' chunky salsa and the fourth layer was the chopped tomato and green onion (I omitted the green pepper). For the fifth layer, I used guacamole (I live in So Cal and this is a necessity for us) and I covered the guac in shredded cheddar cheese. So, technically, ours was a 6 layer dip but I think it was just perfect this way. Not only was it devoured, but people were also commenting on how good it was and making jokes about how much of it they ate. It is quite possibly one of the easiest dips to make and I can guarantee your guests will not be disappointed. Yum!

Family loved this. made this for dinner one evening. The only thing i did differently was i used 1/2 the pkg of taco seasoning in the sour cream mixture. I cooked 1/2 pound ground beef with the other half of taco seasoning then added the refried beans to the meat mixture. Bottom meat and bean layer is warm then you layer with the other ingredients as noted. Came out very good. Going to make this again for Super Bowl Sunday :D

This was an overall great recipe.  I made a few slight changes.  For one, I mixed a package of taco seasoning with 1 pound of ground beef.  Then I layered like this: 1. Refried beans 2. shredded cheese 3. sour cream/cream cheese 4. ground beef 5. salsa 6. tomatoes 7. olives 8. shredded cheese.  Then I baked it at 350 until everything was warm and the cheese was melted.  After I took it out of the oven I added shredded lettuce.

text:
I agree you either need a 9X13 or maybe two smaller dishes is an even better idea so you can keep one fresh and replace it as needed? I also left out the lettuce simply as I didn’t want it to go soggy after a while. Best TIP… the refried beans mix tends to be too thick and any chips will likely break trying to scoop it up. I take about 2-3 table spoons of the salsa and mix it in with the bean/taco mix. When you do this it will be easier to scoop. I also let the cream cheese warm up a bit to room temperature to make it easier to mix and spread. It is a party hit though…

text:
Tasted awesome and got a lot of compliments from people at two different parties.  I heated the refried beans and added the seasoning so it was easier to spread, didn't use lettuce or green peppers, didn't use all the sour cream mixture, added a layer of guacamole, and I split the recipe between two shallow serving trays.  Everyone liked the thin layers because you got a taste of everything in one scoop.    It is exactly one year later from my original review and this recipe is still being requested at every bbq/party/gathering of any sort that I go to.  There are never any leftovers and people I've never met will find me to tell me how much they've enjoyed it.  Thank you for this recipe!

text:
This dip is the best! I get more compliments on it and never have leftovers. I think the secret is in adding taco seasoning to the beans, although I usually use two cans of beans since one packet of seasoning to one can of beans can be too salty. The cream cheese/sour cream mixture is too die for! A few more tips: Guacamole makes this even better (to save time, I usually use vacuum-sealed guacamole found in the produce section--it tastes really fresh and almost as good as homemade). I also skip the lettuce and green peppers.

text:
A few years ago, I was asked to bring taco dip (which I had never made) to a family gathering for something different... now I'm asked to bring it every time!! My version (which has been tweaked over the years): layer 1- refried beans; layer 2- sour cream, cream cheese, taco seasoning combined; layer 3- guacamole (sometimes from scratch, but often pre-made for time's sake); layer 4- chunky salsa (slightly drained); layer 5- lettuce (finely chopped) and scallions (or chopped onion, depending on my mood); layer 6- shredded cheddar cheese (or a hybrid of sharp cheeses); layer 7- chopped black olives... serve cold. It's always a hit!

text:
I agree with other reviewers about leaving out the lettuce and green pepper but I always have made this using regular refried beans WITHOUT the taco spice and also using sour cream WITHOUT the cream cheese which is MUCH better.  REASON:  The cream cheese absolutely covers up all flavor from the beans, the cheese, the sauce and the sour cream!  UGH!  It is so heavy and bland and just coats everything with ZERO taste! :(  Why ruin all the spicy flavors!  Then you don't need to add the fake taste you get with the taco spice.  Leave out the cream cheese and it's a winner!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe often with a few alterations.  As a "secret ingredient" I add cubed Velveeta (~1/2 lb) to the refried beans (and I've had people tell me they love this dip even though they usually don't like refried beans), heat in small pan until melted and just add 1/2 of the envelope of taco seasoning mix and a little of the salsa.  When the velveeta is melted I spread the mixture in a large pie plate and refrigerate it.  Then I mix the room temperature cream cheese with a hand mixer until smooth, then add the sour cream and the other half of the taco seasoning mix...this is how to prevent the lumps.  I never add green pepper or olives and sometimes skip the lettuce too.  This dip always disappears!

text:
Delicious with slight modifications. I doubled the recipe. So I mixed 2 cans of refried beans with one taco seasoning overnight and 1/2 of a serving of Taco Seasoning I by Bill Echols--it didn't make a difference. I put the remaining Taco Seasoning I in the sour cream/cream cheese mixture and let it sit overnight. Also used 2 jars of thick and chunky salsa and draining overnight eliminated two cups of water from the salsa. Layer 1-beans, layer 2-cream cheese, sour cream w/taco seasoning, layer 3-tomatoes, layer 4-green onions, layer 5-gucamole, layer 6-drained thick and chunky salsa, layer 7-cheese, layer 8-black olives. It keeps well in the fridge for at least a week. Next time I will put the taco seasoning in the sour cream mixture not the beans. I have also made it with Rotel vs. salsa which works well and is cheaper.

text:
This dip was fantastic!  I did make a couple of changes, though.  First, I mixed a pound of ground beef with the refried beans (I cooked the hamburger in about 3/4 of the taco seasoning).  Secondly, I added 1/4 of the taco seasoning to the sour cream/cream cheese layer for a little extra taste.  Third, I used half cheddar cheese and half taco cheese for some extra Mexican flavoring.  Finally, I didn't use lettuce after reading some of the reviews, but I'm sure that had no affect on the taste.  I will absolutely make this again!

text:
This is fabulous! I made it last year for super bowl (with some alterations for preference) and it was devoured! I was asked to make it again this year, and again, completely devoured! This is a keeper for sure. Here's what I did differently; I cooked 1 lb ground beef with taco seasoning, and mixed with the refried beans, left out most of the veggies, and layered as follows (from bottom to top):

1) Ground beef/refried bean mixture
2) Sour cream/cream cheese mixture
3) Chunky Salsa
4) Shredded Cheese
5) Olives

Last year I served it cold and this year I served it warm (baked at 375 for about 20 min) and it tastes delicious both ways! Wonderful recipe! Can't say enough good things about this!

text:
This a great dip recipe to which I made some changes to due to personal preference and some of the other reviewers tips.  So many other reviewers said they did not have enough bean dip to cover the bottom of the pan called for in the recipe and some actually bought a smaller sized glass dish. Instead, I bought an extra can of bean dip, and that problem was solved.  Also, I do not add the taco seasoning to the bean dip.  I add it to the sour cream and cream cheese mixture because I think the flavors blend nicely together in the dip, rather than getting it in one kind of raw, spicy tasting scoop of the beam dip.  I also used 16 ounces of fresh salsa and added a layer of homemade guacamole.  I also skip the green pepper and shredded lettuce.  I received a lot of compliments on this dish and it was devoured!

I've used this recipe many times, and once again last night, somebody asked me for the recipe.  So I just had to add my comments here too.  This recipe is a winner - it never fails to generate at least one request for the recipe.  My version is fairly different though.  I use black beans instead of refried beans.  I don't use lettuce or tomato, but sometimes use canned corn, or avocado slices or even guacamole.  I also put the black olives under the cheese, as I prefer the appearance of the heap of cheddar, rather than of the black olives.  But it's always well-loved.  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
I made this dish for a party at work.  I have never had a seven layer salad before so I had no idea how it was suppose to taste.  The changes I made based on the other reviewers--I added 1 pound of ground beef as the second layer (after the beans), I added 1/2 pack of taco seasonings to the sour cream, use thick and chunky salsa and I left out the lettuce.  The party started at 11:00.  I went to get food at 11:15 and the salad was already half gone and one co-worker was just hanging out by the bowl. By 11:45 there was nothing left.  Everyone raved on how great this was!! Great recipe.

text:
i absolutely LOVE this recipe and as a lot of other reviewers did i made a few variations.. i skipped the lettuce, as i really dont think it adds much to the taste, its more of a 'filler' imo. i made this for a superbowl party and it was a HUGE hit! i will definitely make this again! i made this with 10 yummy layers 1) can of refried beans spread evenly 2) approximately a pound of cooked ground beef cooked with 1/2 pkt of taco seasoning 3) home-made chunky guacamole (thats to die for if i may say so myself) :) 4) sour cream mixed with the remaining 1/2 pkt of taco seasoning 5) shredded sharp cheddar cheese 6) 1 small can of mild green chiles (drained) 7) chunky salsa (drained) 8) sliced black olives 9) fresh tomatoes 10) green onions

text:
This recipe deserves five stars because it's so quick, simple, and versatile.  I brought it to a party and everyone enjoyed it-- I didn't take home any leftovers. I cut the amount of sour cream/cream cheese in half and added some taco seasoning to it as well as the beans, used medium salsa and a can of Rotel drained for the veggie layers, and added chopped black olives under the cheese.  It took a few minutes to throw together and stick in the fridge (I did it a few hours before the party).  Will use it again when I need something quick to bring.  Thanks!

text:
Great recipe! I use a cookie sheet or a large piece of cardboard covered in foil to put all the goodies on! I also get large tortillas and spread them out on the sheet or board, overlapping them to within an inch or two from the edges. Spread all the ingredients and have a feast. When down just a little left on the tortillas, roll them up and slice into 2 inch pieces. I guarantee nothing will be left! Easy clean up, too!

text:
Its a really good recipe. I see that some people seem to think you heat the beans up before you spread them but you don't they are done coming straight out the can. this dip is either a cold dip or room temp dip. You can mix and match what veggies you want to use and even omit the cream cheese which I don't use. I do recommend draining the salsa your dip will become watery and look uninviting if you don't. This never lasts long when I make it.

I've been making this for years, except I use cumin and chili powder instead of the taco seasoning. . .but. . .really the same thing.  I've been reading reviews and people are commenting on serving dishes.  This is really pretty if you use a platter, round is best but oval like in the pic is okay too.  You leave and edge of each ingredient showing so that your guests can see what's in it, it also looks really pretty like that.  If you put the cheese on top of the beans instead of on top of the lettuce, the lettuce doesn't get weighed down as much.  Okay. . .now I want some 7 layer dip!

We've made this a couple times now - here's the changes I make. Start with the beans/seasoning mix, add sour cream mix, then added a guacamole layer. Topped that with fresh homemade pico (tomato/onion/cilantro/lime/salt) instead of salsa. Then shredded cheese, black olives and green onions on top. We don't use the lettuce or bell pepper out of personal preference. Great dip for potlucks or parties.

text:
This doesn't have lots of flavor but it is a good and easy appetizer.  I followed the recipe exactly, except for leaving off the lettuce since others indicated it gets soggy.  I used a 9" x 13" pan, baked at 350 degrees for 30 minutes, and served it warm with Fritos "Scoop" corn chips.  However, my husband took it to work the next day and his coworkers thought it was good cold (room temp).  I think next time I make this, I will try adding just a bit of ground meat and maybe Rotel (drained) instead of regular diced tomatoes.  It is good as is but I think it needs more flavor and/or spice.

Due to diet restrictions I made this with Fat Free Cream Cheese and Fat Free Sour Cream, as well as, reduced fat cheese. I served this in a small trifle bowl and it was beautiful. text:
Unlike some others, I really like that this recipe uses shredded iceberg instead of a layer of guacamole.  The result is a slightly different twist by adding some crisp freshness in with the softer ingredients as oppose to just layers and layers of softness.  If you don't want your lettuce to go soft, keep the dip in the fridge prior to serving. And as long is it's served in a controlled environment, it will withstand several hours outside of the fridge.  I got RAVE reviews and will indeed be making it again.

country:
None
text:
This is the best 7 layer dip ever... period. The only changes I made were to add a little bit of the taco seasoning to the cream cheese mix (and I used the "Taco Seasoning I" recipe off of this site... so good), I used 8 oz. Safeway brand Southwest Salsa, 8 oz Safeway brand Peach-Pineapple Salsa, added a can of corn, and instead of cheddar I used a Mexican Monteray Jack and Cheddar blend. I will never use another 7 layer dip recipe. This is IT! I used Tostitos to scoop it all up. My only recommendation is to the smash the cream cheese and sour cream with a fork to get an even consistancy. This dish is awesome! I tried to make it into burritos the next day, but after heating them up in the microwave, they turned out runny (yet still good). After day 2 the dip is just as amazing as day 1, if not more so. I even took a spoon to this! You don't need chips, just a spoon, it's so good! I can't say enough about this one... definitely a keeper!

text:
I need 10 stars for this one!  My guests LOVED this recipe and I had to share it with everyone before they left.  

I made minor changes.  I heated each layer before serving cause I like it served warm and I used ground meat instead of beans. 

So, I mixed the meat and some cheddar in a bowl and heated it to melt the cheese.  Then I mixed the sour cream and cream cheese and put it on top of the meat. Finally I mixed salsa with more cheedar and heated it then placed it on top of the sour cream.  Then I just added all the toppings.  It looks and tastes awesome!  Make sure you use a big serving dish (deep too).

Brought this to a Super Bowl party. I added a layer of shredded chicken and used blue runner red kidney beans instead of the refried beans (I don't really like refried beans). Also left out the black olives, green peppers and green onions (I added finely diced onions to the guacamole) and added a layer of  homemade guacamole. I did use shredded green leaf lettuce. I will make again with a few variations, but overall it was very tasty!

userID:
10530549
Display Name:
iannacca
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1382705.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice recipe, I took in part the suggestions of Janet Dufor and JULIEWNEK (thanks to both!) and added my own twist, substituting lettuce (for the sogginess issue) and green bell pepper (my son does not like them) with a simple guacamole, which I made just mashing 5-6 avodacos, adding chili powder and cumin to taste, the juice of a lime (can use 1/2 too) and about 4-6 oz of creamy goat cheese. I used ~ 1lb. of 85% lean ground turkey for the taco meat, also spiced up with the taco seasoning mix (but added chili powder and cumin to taste to this too because the mix I had was a bit wimpy). I also warmed up the refried beans before spreading them (added a bit of water to it to make is a bit creamier, o/w too guey straight out of the can, can use chicken stock too). I had a large platter (and a nice size group!), so I decided to double the beans (2 cans). I also used light sour cream and no cream cheese to cut a bit on calories. I ended up with eight layers, which I arranged as follows (from bottom to top): 1) Refried beans; 2) Turkey taco meat; 3) Shredded Cheddar cheese (melted nicely on top the two warm layers); 4) Sour cream; 5) Salsa; 6) My guacamole; 7) Rotel original recipe tomatoes mixed with chives instead of green onions (either OK I think); 8) Sliced black olives. Great with either tortilla chips of all sorts or even soft corn tortillas (we used a lot of the latter and blue corn chips for some gluten-intolerant people). Everyone loved it!

text:
this was a great recipe, similar to one my mother-in-law makes. it was raved about at several gatherings i have taken this to. but the second time around, along with following occasions, i did make some modifications (which is why i give this 4.5 out of 5 stars). i don't think the green bell peppers fit at all. green chiles or jalapenos might be a nice substitute, but i went without. i also opted to mix the taco seasoning in with the cream cheese & sour cream- that was more flavorful than mixing it with the beans. also added a layer of guacamole on top before the salsa. 1 small head of lettuce was overkill, didn't feel like it was necessary to complete the dish after the first round making it. omitting it made no difference to anyone and the dish was still gone each time it was served. but a great dip, super easy and i would highly recommend it.

text:
I add jalapenos (2-3) to the green pepper (make sure they are not wet) and omit the black olives . I also use hot salsa and "spicy" (lol) taco seasoning and "spicy" re-fried beans if I can find them(if not, I use fat free). I would recommend seeding the tomato before chopping it and use "reduced fat" cream cheese (fat free is a MISTAKE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!). I LOVE this dip though. It's basic, but really tasty. I eat it with tortilla, carrots, or tortilla chips. Additionally, I like a sharp cheese (nothing too milky/bland). Finally...it does get watery after the first day, so presentation may be a concern...If you don't mind, just drain off the salsa/lettuce water :)

text:
I used this recipe as an inspiration because I'd never mixed cream cheese with the sour cream layer in my version of this dip before; the idea intrigued me but I added a can of chopped jalapeno chilis to it for added punch.   I mixed a can of seasoned chili beans, lightly mashed, with the refiried beans because I didn't think ther was enough of the bean layer compared to the sour cream layer.  It loosened the refrieds and add flavor (I didn't have taco seasoning, as well).  I also added a layer of guacamole to this dip.  I really liked the addition of the cream cheese to the sour cream.  Thanks for this!

I made this dip for a potluck at work and everyone was raving about it! There was so much food at the potluck and my dip was the only thing that ran out! I'm already getting requests to make it again. The quality of the ingredients makes a difference. I used Philadelphia Cream Cheese, Pace salsa, freshly grated Cracker Barrel Sharp Cheddar Cheese, etc. Also, I omitted the lettuce and added cilantro on top for an extra boost of flavor. Definitely make this in a 13x9x2 pan. It fits very nicely.

text:
Amazing, everyone loved this dip.  However, I made a change or two.  For starters I made my own refried black beans and doubled the amount.  I used two 15oz cans of black beans (drain but not completely), mashed them in a sauce pan, heated until warm, and added the following spices to taste: cumin, turick, white pepper, black pepper, salt, garlic, chili powder, and a little bit of oil.  Continue to heat until spices and oil are mixed in throughly.  Remove from heat add one and a half packets of taco seasoning. Any more and it will be too salty.  I also used yellow onions instead of green.  The taste was there, but I am sure the green onions give a better presentation.  But I used what was in the house because we are on a budget.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Terrific receipe. I realized today as I was making it that I hadn't reviewed it and I've been using this for years. I do have one big change which I recommend: I have found that the amount of sour cream and cream cheese to be too much; I basically halve the amount of both ingredients and mix THAT with the taco seasoning mix. That seems to be the "punch" the dish needs and what everyone notices as being "unique" from other taco dips. I use "spicy refried beans" too. I spread the beans, top with the sour cream mixture and let it sit overnight which really helps meld the flavor. If you can get fresh salsa (or make it yourself), it adds a nice freshness to the dish. I omit the green pepper and tomato and instead mix green onions with a one can of diced chilies which is very yummy. I use all the other ingredients. Very easy dish to customize.

This was good. I omitted the lettuce and green pepper and used a black bean/corn salsa. The thought of canned olives is unappealing to me so I used green olives from a jar instead. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making this type of dip and it turned out quite well.  I did make a few minor modifications which I strongly recommend.  The changes are as follows: 1)Add half of the taco mix to the beans and add the other half of the mix to the cream cheese and sour cream mixture. 2) Leave out the lettuce, green onions, and tomatoes.  3) In place of the letteuce, green onions, and tomatoes add guacamole.  The guacomle should include onions and tomatoes mixed in (use one of the highly rated guacamole recipes on this website).  4) Layer the dip in the following order: beans (bottom), cream cheese/sour cream, guacamole, salsa, and cheese (top).

text:
I've been making this for a few years now and my family and friends still ask me to make it!  In fact my MIL asked me to make it for her to bring to a party that I wasn't even invited too!  This dip is that good!

Start with a 9x13 glass pan (it's pretty to look at it through the glass).  I omit the bell pepper, use pinto beans (doubled to 32oz) and simmer them in water until softened -about 20 minutes - to refry them myself (I consider it healthier).  Sometimes, I'll use red onion instead, and always top it off with Jalepenos!  This will chill well, but be warned, only tough chips will do, unless you're using spoons.

text:
Excellent!   I did make some simple changes based upon other reviews...used BLACK re fried beans (preference), added a layer of guac atop the crm cheez/sour crm mixture,  drained the salsa (needed 2 jars),  NO peppers, tomatoes or lettuce. Lots of cheez then the blk olives and green onions.  Theses changes really did not alter the taste of the recipe much, just kept it from being a wet mess. I will make this again and again...red peppers, corn, jalapeños may be added. I will also cut back on the amounts of sour cream and cream cheese...12 oz and 6 oz respectively...there was just too much. I used an 8X8 Pyrex. EASY AND DELCIOUS!

text:
Great recipe and just what I was looking for! I was feeling a little lazy and got prechopped lettuce and tomatoes, so this was super quick too! Used low fat cream cheese and sour cream and it still tasted fabulous.

Next time I would either half the cream cheese/sour cream mixture or double the beans, Seemed a little off, but that's ok. I put some seasoning in the beans, but a majority of it in the cc/sc mixture, which i saw in another recipe. I could have eaten that alone! I layered the beans, cheese mixture and salsa and put it in the fridge to sort of marinate, and put the rest of the toppings on right before I served it. Left out the peppers and onions. Didn't seem right to me, and just enough olives on top for a lovely presentation. 

About the wateryness people are complaining about: Might be the salsa you're using. I used one that's real thick and chunky and that seemed to help. It was only after a few days in the fridge that it started to look a little watery. Was still yummy though.

text:
Delicious!  I added a layer of Bob Cody's guacamole from this site, and omitted the chopped pepper.  Since I wanted to take this on a weekend camping trip, I didn't use fresh tomatoes or salsa because I was afraid it would get watery.  After reading other reviews, I used 2 cans of very well drained diced tomatoes with green chiles instead.  It worked out perfectly, and we were able to munch on it all weekend.  Everyone loved it.  I gave the recipe 5 stars in spite of making some changes to it because my changes were only to make it keep longer.   Preparing it as written is delicious and works out great if you're serving it the same day.

text:
I made this for an after church gathering, and it was a huge hit.  I served it with Fritos Scoops instead of tortilla chips because they are a sturdier chip and can really "grab" all the yummy flavors.  Like other reviews, I agree that the beans and taco mixed together are very salty- so much so that I almost ditched the recipe at the beginning. However, when you add all the mild (sometimes bland if eaten alone) flavors of the veggies, sour cream, and cream cheese, it balances out great.  You've got to get every layer in your bite! lol  That's where the handiness of the scoops come in.  I also agree that the suggested size serving dish is too small.  Great go-to recipe in a pinch or for a party!

Made this as an appetizer for the Superbowl.  The overall flavor was good, could have been a little spicier. I added a layer of homemade guacamole and then black beans on top of the sour cream/cream cheese layer and omitted the lettuce.  My biggest disappointment was how watery it was. text:
This is super easy and pretty forgiving as well as easy to change depending on what you have on hand. I'd definately make it in a 9 by 13 pan when I  make it again and use two cans of beans rather than one. We skip the green pepper but everything else was exactly as listed in the recipe. It was overflowing our pan because after reading the reviews we decided to use the 8 by 11. Anyway all in all a great recipe. We make it the night before but then add the veggies just before serving otherwise it can get a bit "wet" from the lettuce and tomatoes.

userID:

Display Name:
sutra

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came across something like this years ago but haven't made it in a while.  I changed up a few things and it was great.  I used 2 cans beans because one wasn't enough then did the cream cheese sour cream, then chop meat, layer guac, cheddar, salsa, green onions and olives, more cheddar baked for 30 min then topped with lettice and tomato.  If by chance you have any left it tastes great cold the next day. 
The 2 reoccurring low reviews talked about it being runny and not spicy enough. How about draining some of the extra water out of the salsa. As far as the seasoning goes, you can spice up just about every layer until it suits your tastes. Use jalepenos, tabasco, spicy salsa and guac (if you used it) Being able to control the level of seasoning in this is one of the positives. I've made it in three smaller trays one mild, one medium and one on fire. There is never a bite left of any.

Next time, I will omit the green peppers and lettuce because I didn't care for them in this dip and add a layer of guacamole. I will also do what a few other reviewers suggested and put some seasoning in the sour cream/cream cheese layer.  Overall, 4 stars for the original recipe!

city:

country:

text:
This turned out great!!  It made two pie plates worth, one spicy, one not.  For the spicy one, I mixed 1/2 can green chillies with 1/2 the taco seasoning into the beans and spread in the bottom of the pie plate, mixed the fat free cream cheese and fat free sour cream, 1/2 the taco seasoning, 1/2 can green chillies and spread that on the bean layer, spread the medium salsa next, layered light cheddar cheese and Jalapeno Monteray jack, then diced green onions and diced tomatoes, sliced olives and diced & sliced jalapeno pepper.  Baked in oven at 350 for 30 minutes and served with toasted baguette slices and assorted crackers.  It was a huge hit!!  Thanks for sharing your recipe!!

country:
None
text:
I made this last night for a party and it was a big hit.  I gave it 4 stars because, as written, it would have been too mild for the crowd I run with.  Here are the modifications I made. After reading that this dish can come out runny, I cut back on the salsa to about 3/4 of what was called for.  Also, I used roma tomatoes-  I cut out the seeds and only used the flesh.  For the sour cream and cream cheese mix, I added cayene pepper and a splash of lemon juice for a little extra zip.  I also used diced fresh jalepenos as we Texans like the heat!  I too omitted the letuce for fear that if it were sitting out for too long, it would wilt.  I will definately be making this again!

Delicious! To start with, I didn't use lettuce, green onions, or peppers, and I didn't use the taco seasoning. I put this in a 2-quart casserole as I planned to bake it.   I used the beans for the first layer, then the cream cheese/sour cream mixture for the second layer, homemade guacamole for layer three, diced tomatoes next, then sliced olives, then salsa (I used fresh chunky salsa and drained it well). I covered it entirely in shredded cheddar and baked at 350 for about 35 minutes.   It was a total hit with everyone who was there, and I handed out the recipe to a lot of people who tried it. Thanks!

text:
I love this recipe, but like others tweeked it to my personal taste.  I added a layer of taco seasoned chopped chicken or ground beef after the beans.  Then added chopped bell pepper, onion, green onion, and tomato.  Topped that with shredded mexican cheese and melt in the oven.  Next I add a layer of salsa,a layer of lettuce, a layer of guacamole and a layer of the sour cream mixture. Lastly I sparcely top the sour cream with the leftover chopped vegetable and sliced black olives.  This recipe is both hot and cold when immediately served, beautiful to look at through a glass serving bowl, and I never have any leftover to bring back when I bring it to parties

country:
None
text:
I used to bring this dip to parties years ago and was happy to find it again. I made a few changes: Use cilantro/tomato instead of salsa, add 5 mashed avocados mixed with lime juice and garlic, cooked the refried beans in some bacon fat and added garlic...then whipped in a little milk to make it creamy. Top with roasted green chilies, tomatoes, olives,a little bit of onion and mexican cheese.
Then, go on a serious diet for about 3 days because this recipe is full of calories and fat...but very good!

text:
This is similar to a recipe I used 40 years ago.   I mixed an 8 oz container of French Onion Dip instead of cream cheese with the sour cream.  I also put the toppings in individual bowls and we add our own.  We dip the amount of the dip we want and warm it in the microwave for 15-20 seconds...then we add our toppings.  Toppings:  jalapeños, lettuce onions, avocados,.  I layer the green chilies and sliced olives.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4020691.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Could not stop eating! Instead of standard retried beans I used 3 28oz cans of Goya red kidney beans. I warmed them up in a pot. I mixed Picante Medium Salsa in the beans about 8oz or so. Also mixed two packs of Sazon. Mixed them together cooked for about ten minutes. I drained the beans and mixed three packs of Taco seasoning. Instead of lettuce I used guacamole. I would have made my own but I was in a rush so I used 4 11oz jars of Herrs Guacamole & believe it or not their guacamole has a lot of flavor- it's just not thick. I also skipped the green onions. I did & used everything else as the recipe shows. Great, easy party favorite.

I made this for a pig roast the other night and it was a huge hit.  Within two hours of opening the lid it was completely gone.  I followed the recipe exactly the first time.  I made it again last night for some friends but I cut the sour cream/cream cheese mixture in half and I enjoyed it even more. I also found a chunkier, hotter salsa than I had used before. text:
I've been looking for a really good layered dip and I've found it! The only changes I made was I put "two cans of refried beans with roasted chiles" into the taco mix (all I could taste with one can was salt, two cans were perfect) I did use all the beans which was good, but next time I think I'll only use half and save half for another time. I also used "light" sour cream and "reduced calorie" cream cheese, and I could not tell the difference. Also I did the layers the same EXCEPT I switched it around when it came to the lettuce, cheese and olives. I put the shredded cheddar cheese, then the lettuce, then the olives. I found I liked the look of it better, AND I could make the layered dip a day ahead (up to the cheese layer), then the next day I chopped up the lettuce (so no wilting and stayed crisp), then added the olives. This took hardly any time to do that, and I think this tastes better if made a day ahead. I'm not one for very spicy food, but I liked the flavor of this without all the heat. If you do like it hotter you can spice it up by using refried beans with a lot more kick. One more thing I'll mention (I know someone else commented) in the video I was turned off by her whole hand (up to her knuckle) going into the dip when she scooped it out with the chip. My solution for this is I put a tablespoon in the dish, so people could scoop it out with the spoon and put it on the nacho chip (worked for me). I will be making this again. Thank you Sue for a great recipe!

text:
Not a good taco dip recipe.  It wants to be a salad but has a multiple-personality disorder.  No one ate this at the party I took it to.  I followed the recipe exactly.  The taco spices should NOT be mixed with the beans as it makes them too salty and the spices taste raw.  Better to mix them with the sour cream mixture.  Also, the lettuce and green peppers had no business being there.  The green peppers took away from the over-all dish and the lettuce just ended up being watery and wilted.  I ended up taking the entire dish home and trying to eat it throughout the week as a chicken taco salad just to not waste it all.  I will not be making this again.

userID:
773534
Display Name:
Carol Saylor
isPro:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had to come up with inexpensive but tasty munchies for 200 people for a friends 80th birthday party and made this - quadrupled the recipe, using the "Refried Beans without the Refry" from this site.  Also made salsa since several of us putting the party together had tomatoes from the garden. Made it for a Christmas party and Chamber of Commerce After Hours gathering according to recipe, it is economical, feeds a lot of people and is just great!!!!!!  As one friend said, tasting it for the first time "it's one of those tastes that has so many flavors you just want to keep eating it!"  After making this so many times, a few easy tips.  I used greek yogurt instead of sour cream.  It's a great replacement for anything calling for sour cream.  Rotel Diced tomatoes with chilies (Mild)(or your grocery store House brand) is an inexpensive replacement for Salsa, if you stock up on it as I do when its on sale.  Zip it up with some bottled hot sauce.  I have also used canned diced tomatoes, canned chilies and some of the taco  seasoning for the salsa layer.  I bought some ready made guacamole for a "special" party and layered it in.  I don't think anyone was counting the layers!!

This is SO good!   Next time I make it I am going to cut the cream cheese and sour cream in half. text:
I don't think this could be emphasized enough... drain the salsa!! I had read that some people did it, but I chose to skip it when I made it. Big mistake! It was soupy.  It didn't ruin the dish, it just didn't look as nice. Also, I baked mine at 350 for 15 minutes, just enough to melt the cheese and heat everything to a similar temperature. I added hamburger to my taco sauce (skipped the beans) and it was good! I couldn't stand the thought of warm hamburger, that's why I heated it. Plus, I saw another reviewer did the same. We made this a main meal!

It is definitely a very presentable snack to be displayed on the table. I made this for Christmas eve family gathering and my family loves it. So good you can't stop eating!! I love it w/ the lettuce and I also like to add some fresh cilantro. You can't go wrong. Add or leave out what you want. It's awesome. ******UPDATE*****.  I think there is too much sour cream/ cream cheese for the amount of beans, so next time I will either use 2 cans of beans or cut the sour cream/cream cheese in half. text:
This was a good recipe.  It is very versatile and you can add or delete ingredients as you like.  I made it for a party and it was a hit.  One tip, though, if you want to make it the night before it is easy to do except for the topping.  The lettuce wilted and absorbed the salsa and didn't look quite as pretty but it still tasted good.  Just put all the other ingredients in the dish and have your chopping done and add the lettuce, green peppers, and olives right before you serve it.  Easy and pretty.

text:
Changed this up a bit per other reviewer's suggestions.  Added a layer of store bought guac., added some green onions to the cream cheese/ sour cream mixture as well as on top.  Omitted the lettuce, tomatoes, and bell peppers because we made it to have around for a few days to snack on and diddn't think these ingredients would hold up well for maore than a day.  Also, used low sodium taco seasoning.  We like it alot.  I made it in a casserole dish but next time I will use a 9x13 pan as the instructions state so that the layers will be thinner and easier to dip chips into.  With the deep casserole dish you kind of went layer by layer when dipping intead of getting some of each ingredient.  Will make this again.

text:
As per other reviews I added guac atop the sour cream mixture, and seasoned ground beef atop the beans, drained the salsa I used a 9x13 pyrex. The presentation looked nice through the glass. Altough I had to use a can and a half of beans because 1 can did not cover the bottom. It turned out supper yummy and was a big party hit. I ate it with Tostitos white corn chips but next time I will try a thicker corn chip because the dip is very heavy and the chips tended to break. I doubled the recipe and made 7 layer burritos for dinner the next night. Was ever better the second day. Will def make again.

text:
I have made this a dozen times in the last year.  After finding this recipe, I threw out all my other recipes for mexican layered dips.  I love that you can now buy taco shredded lettuce because that saves a few minutes and also gives a thinner lettuce strip.  Also we buy taco seasoning in a quart bulk container in the spice section at Costco and it is only 5 bucks so well worth it if you use taco spice very often . It tastes just like the little individual packets.  I use 2 Tablespoons for 1 -1 oz packet.  Delicious!  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I'm a taco purist as far as the veggies go, so I leave out the bell peppers and onions, but keep the tomatoes and lettuce.  Just make sure the lettuce is very finely chopped.  One thing I often do, just for ease of making it, is substitute the taco seasoning and refried beans for the hot bean dip you can buy in almost any store.  Saves a step.  I also don't necessarily heat this one up - it's just as good cold, or room temperature.  Sometimes I also add guacamole - just depends on my mood at the time.

country:
None
text:
Love having any excuse to make this! It's always a hit and disappears fast! I used McCormick original taco seasoning which is 1.25 oz so I only used a little over half mixed in with my traditional Rosaria refried beans. Next I did the cream cheese/sour cream layer as is then I used Sabra pico de gallo salsa and used a slotted spoon so I would just get the chunky stuff and barely any juice.  I left out the lettuce since so many other people did and I just topped those three layers with a bag (2 cups) of Shredded Mexican cheese and topped that with sliced olives and green onions. Best bean dip ever!

Great recipe! The only thing I did differently was mix half of the packet of the taco seasoning in the beans. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5421929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great, basic recipe and is perfect for parties!  I made it for my family Christmas party and it got raves...it serves a lot of people, too!  I think the only thing I would do differently next time is use a hot salsa or add some sliced jalapenos (because I would like it spicier), but it's nice you can customize to your guests' tastes.  Definitely use a chunky salsa so that it holds up better and doesn't make the sour cream mixture runny.  I also tried to layer the "sturdier" ingredients, i.e. peppers, lettuce, etc. against the sour cream mix and THEN put down the salsa so that it didn't get too messy.  All in all, a keeper! Would be really pretty in a clear glass bowl, too, so you can see the layers.

I made this for the first time last Christmas, omiting the olives as I don't like them. It was delicious, but have made a few minor tweeks. I don't use the lettuce as you can't dip thru it, and if it sits out for too long or by some strange reason the dip doesn't get eaten all at once and you have to put it back in the fridge, the lettuce tends to wilt and get soggy. Also like one other member said, it can be made a little healthier by using low fat sour cream, cream cheese and cheddar and low sodium taco seasoning. If i want some extra heat I add Jalapenos in place of the olives. This recipe is so versatile and you can modify it to suit your needs

text:
With a few modifications I really liked this dish. Instead of refried beans I sauted half a red onion, 1/2 cup tomato sauce, 1/4 cup salsa and 16oz drained and rinsed black beans with 1/2 pkg. of taco season. I also added 1/2 cup homemade ranch dressing to the cream cheese(1/3fat) mixture and used fat free sour cream. The final addition was yellow and red bell peppers and cilantro. Great recipe!! This is a crowd pleaser!!

I love this dip, and my family keeps asking me to bring it to parties. I usually leave out the lettuce and use Colby and Monterey Jack cheese instead of cheddar. It's easy to moderate the spiciness by using hot or mild salsa and adding other spices, but my family prefers the mild version.

country:
None
text:
I love this for a quick and easy appetizer for a big crowd. It's easy to use what you have on hand too! I prefer to mix the taco seasoning into the sour cream, minus the cream cheese, instead of mixing into the beans. Also, if expecting leftovers I recommend a light layer of salsa due to it getting a bit watery if kept a few days.The ice berg lettuce can easily be subtracted and I typically use a finely shredded mexican cheese blend, cheddar is a bit too coarse. Also a guacamole layer is a tasty addition!

userID:
2452459
Display Name:
jillmg

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dip is ALWAYS a winner! Like others, I did make some modifications. One can of refried beans is not enough, you will need two (which I warmed up a bit in the microwave first to make it easier to stir)- and, I only used 1/2 a packet of taco seasoning (a full packet may overwhelm the overall taste). I also made homeade quacamole (I used five avacados for this recipe) and used in lieu of the lettuce, which I feel adds a ton of flavor. Instead of salsa, I used two cans of drained chopped tomates with green chilies (which will avoid the dip getting watery). I also left out the green pepper, which is a personal preference. I layered the beans first, the followed with the sour cream/cream cheese mixture, then the quacamole, the tomatoes, the cheese, then topped with sliced black and green olives and green onions. I have yet to meet anyone who has not loved this dip!

text:
Absolutely fantastic dip!  I'm glad I read some reviews of people suggesting what size dish to use - I don't see how this would fit in anything other than a 13x9.  That dish was full by the time I was done layering!  I did as others suggested and mixed the taco seasoning in with the sour cream, cream cheese mixture and the combination was just delicious.  I made this and refrigerated it overnight before serving so I left out the lettuce to avoid the wilt factor.  It wasn't missed, the other veggies are plenty.  If you're entertaining less than 6 or 7 people I'd considering halving the recipe.

text:
I made this for a dinner party last week and it was a HUGE hit. I thought it had made way more than we needed but by the time dinner came around, there was only a little bit of this left!  I used 1/2 the packet of taco seasoning for the re-fried beans and the other 1/2 for the sour cream layer. I also didn't use the entire container of sour cream, only about 2/3. I omitted the tomato since the salsa seemed to be more than enough and also cut back on the lettuce and olives. I didn't have a 9x13 dish to put this in so I used a 9x9. I thought it might be too thick but people just scooped it out on to appetizer plates and devoured it :) Served with Tostito's scoops. I'm planning to make this for another party this weekend and am going to try adding in a layer of guacamole as other reviewers suggested.

text:
I used a 9x13 pyrex dish and blended the beans with a hand mixer with half of the taco seasoning. I spread them in the dish and it looked way too thin so I added another can of beans with more seasoning. Then I did the sourcream/creamcheese/rest of the seasoning blended, guacamole, green onion, olive, tomato and then the salsa and cheese. I used medium salsa and mild seasoning and it wasn't spicy tasting. Everyone seemed to love it at my work party!

text:
An easier way to make this dip is to mix the taco seasoning, sour cream, and cream cheese together and use that as your base. then add your toppings. I use onions lettuce tomatos and grated cheese. It's easier, cheaper, and still has amazing taste. Make your toppings out of what you would normally put on tacos. The best thing about this dip is that after you make the base you can put whatever you like on it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! My whole family loves it!! I usually use Taco Bell brand seasoning mix (make sure you don't get fajita or chipotle flavored seasoning mix, it's not as good!) fat-free refried beans (I'm a vegetarian and most regular refried beans have lard in them) hot chunky salsa, I use fresh chopped jalepenos instead of green bell pepper, I leave off the green onions and only put tomato in half (a lot of people in my family don't like tomato!). Instead of mixing the taco seasoning with the refried beans, I mix it in with the cream cheese and sour cream. I usually top it off with shredded "taco blend cheese" (has taco seasoning in it) instead of cheddar cheese.

text:
Okay, this recipe really is perfect as-is.  I needed something for a work Halloween potluck and I struck gold with this one.  Only thing I did was to use 1.5 cans of beans instead of 1.  This way, the entire bottom of my 9x13 glass dish was covered.  Everything else was the same!  Very, very simple and easy to make.  I highly recommend using ALL ingredients on the list.  Fresh veggies really make a difference and so does the shredded lettuce.  I did the bottom 2 layers (beans/seasoning and cream cheese/sour cream) the night before and let them chill overnight.  Half an hour before the party, I then added my salsa layer, then lettuce w/ veggies, then cheese then olives...PERFECTION.  The entire dish was gone first bf all of the other dishes!  Everyone was raving about it.  I really couldn't believe the positive reaction.  HIGHLY recommend!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a get together last weekend and everyone liked it.  I took the suggestion of others and mixed the taco seasoning, cream cheese and sour cream together.  I also took the suggestion of others and mixed some diced jalapeno peppers (from the jar) into the refried beans.  I decided not to use the bell pepper as I thought it would over power the dish.  I also didn't use the lettuce because many said it wilted fast.  Overall, I thought this was a good recipe.  However, I will make a few modifications next time ... based on my own taste buds.  I would add a little seasoning salt to the sour cream mixture or perhaps sprinkle a few drops on each layer.  The flavors tasted good together but I felt it could have definitely used more seasoning and spice.  I didn't care for the salsa as it kind of made the dish runny.

I love this recipe, but the first time I made it my salsa was too watery and soon the whole thing was swimming.  Now I use about half the salsa in a thin layer, then literally lay a paper towel over the salsa layer to gently blot the excess moisture before adding the veggies and cheese.  Now it turns out perfectly.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This would be best in a small casserole vs. a square pyrex because of the numerous quantity of ingredients.  Obviously, the bigger the dish, the thinner the layers and the lettuce and so on could fit.  If you go with a very large casserole, use more refried beans.

Don't bother mixing the taco seasoning in with the beans because it's far easier to use a mixer to blend the sour cream/cream cheese and taco seasoning.

I wasn't sure why you'd layer tomatoes and onions over this lg. amount of salsa but it does add a nice texture difference.

Drain the salsa a bit before spreading so it's not so watery.  

I layered bottom to top as follows: 1 Refried Beans 2 Guacamole 3 Sour cream/cream cheese/taco seasoning mixture
4 Salsa 5Chopped mixture of green onion, tomatoes, green pepper, a little bit of green chiles  6 Shredded lettuce  7 Cheese 8 Garnish black olives.

text:
I make this alot for parties, however I change it up a little bit. I use one drained and rinsed can of black beans, mash them lightly and mix them with the can of refried beans and taco seasoning (sometimes I throw in a can of diced green chiles too). I then layer on the guacamole, then a layer of fresh pico de gallo w/ lime juice, then a layer of sour cream. Sprinkle on a light layer of shredded cheese, chopped black olives and green onions. This fit perfectly into a disposable 9x13 aluminum pan. Left out the lettuce, bell pepper and cream cheese because they sounded like odd additions to this dish.

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for a cookout and everyone absolutely raved about it.  I did make a couple of changes.  I omitted the lettuce and bell pepper.  In place of this, I made a faux guacamole.  I had avacado on hand, but no cilantro, lime juice or onion.  So I mashed up the avacado with a couple tablespoons of mayo, pinch of salt and pepper, splash of red wine vinegar to give it a bit of acidity and a dash of cumin and used a couple of the diced tomatoes for the top layer.  Tasted great!  Also, instead of adding the taco seasoning to the beans, I browned up some ground beef and added it to that.  Lastly, to the cream cheese/sour cream mixture I minced up some pickled jalapenos and mixed that in for an added kick.  I layered mine as follows:

Beans
Cream Cheese/Sour Cream 
Ground beef
Guacamole
Shredded cheese
Tomatoes
Olives

Will definitely make again.  Most likely for Sunday football games!

text:
Well, this didn't blow my socks off, but it's still a very good recipe. I added in an easy guacamole and omitted the peppers from the recipe (personal preference). 

It turned out good, but the bean layer was a bit too salty for me. It was partly my mistake (I used 1.5 oz instead of just 1 oz of taco seasoning), but next time I make this, I'll only use 0.5 to 0.75oz of taco seasoning. One can of beans just can't stand up to that much taco seasoning, in my opinion.

text:
WOW this dip was amazing..and somewhat HEALTHY as well... I used fat free refried beans, low fat cream cheese, light sour cream, and multigrain tortilla chips to lessen up the calories! I first layed down the bean mixture, then the cream cheese/sour cream mixture. Then I topped that with some homemade guacamole (avacado is VERY good for you!) I then put the salsa on top of that and topped off with the tomoatos, green onions, green peppers(extra veggies), then the cheese and olives....everyone at our football party absolutly LOVED this dish. I would recommend it to anyone!

text:
My guests loved this when I served it at a recent party. I served it with corn chip scoops. I used two cans of fat free refried beans instead of the recommended one can, but didn't need to double anything else. I also added in a layer of guacamole before the salsa layer (remember to lightly drain the salsa before adding to prevent a watery dish). I used pre-packaged lettuce shreds and left off the green onions and green peppers. The finely shredded cheddar cheese works the best for me. It made a 9x13 pan when made for 56 servings. I would make it again.

text:
I first tasted this dip years ago at a Bingo party.......it is outstanding!  I used a 13x9" glass pan for a lovely presentation.  I noticed that lots of people think the taco seasoning is too salty......Old El Paso makes a reduced sodium one that is really great.  I am thinking of using Green Giant Mexicorn (if it is still being made)instead of another member's idea of making a corn layer.  I like the idea of black beans on top, instead of olives, since not everybody likes olives.  This dip is too yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was definitely good, and I made it for a Christmas gathering, a time of year that our family is accustomed to having Mexican food. It made a gorgeous presentation. However, there are a few men in the family who don't like green pepper, so I omitted that. Plus, the taco seasoning kind of gives the beans a strange after-taste. It might just be me, but my sisters said that they always left off the taco seasoning as well. Sometimes we add ground beef to it just after the cheese layer if we want to make it more of a meal. Another plus is to get some takeout refried beans from a Mexican restaurant to put in it--somehow they just make it better, if I can remember to do that during all the hustle and bustle of the shopping, etc. But it is a beautiful dip and makes a gorgeous presentation. I like to serve it in a large, round bowl that has straight sides, almost like a trifle serving dish. I found something very festive at a local discount chain that was partly transparent so the guests could see the different layers through the sides. Beautiful!

I removed the bell pepper, replaced the lettuce with Guacamole and put the taco seasoning on a pound of ground beef. 

I layered it bottom first as follows:

Beans
Sour Cream/Cream Cheese mix
Taco Seasoned Ground Beef
Salsa
Guacamole
Tomatoes
Cheese

I actually made it the night before to let the flavors sit in a little and it was awesome. More filling than you would think.

text:
I made this recipe in lieu of buying a dip for an anniversary party.  I doubled the batch and did it on a 16" square heavy duty plastic tray... good idea on the heavy duty LOL.  I bought the restaurant-style refried beans and mixed with taco seasoning.  Then a layer of the cream cheese/sour cream, topped with cooked taco meat, then chunky salsa that I had drained, then olives, green onions, and cheese.  I knew it would be sitting out so I opted out of lettuce and thought that if I did salsa AND tomatoes, that would be a bit overkill.  I had the taco meat to use, that's why I threw it in.  I know, don't rate it if you didn't make it exactly like the recipe and I completely agree.  In this case though, I went searching specifically for this recipe knowing what ingredients I had and was going to use, and this dip was gone by the end of the evening.

I have made this taco dip several times now, and it is the envy of every party i go to. last time i made this i had to make two just to satisfy everyone. can't go wrong with this. i switched the cream cheese to mayonnaise.

 i don't use salsa. i make my own pico de gayo, with cilantro, onions, balsamic vinegar, tomatoes, green onion, and green peppers. This gives it a way better flavor!

i also don't use black olives (personal preference) or lettuce since the pico de gayo has plenty of green with the cilantro, green peppers, and green onions

text:
OK.  I do not put taco seasoning in the sour cream.  No need with all the other natural flavors.  Besides all taco seasoning I've ever used has an artificial taste.  Use other spices if you need to.  Also, this tastes great with Monterrey Jack cheese instead of cheddar.  And you don't need more tomatoes (although I love lots of tomatoes) if you do as one reviewer said and drain the chunky salsa.  Lots of ways to do 5 or 6 or 7 or more layered dip.  And I'm sure everyone has her/his favorite.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Over the years I have made this recipe and it has evolved into an AMAZING one. I use low-fat sour cream and cream cheese, as well as fat free refried beans that are seasoned with a mix of spices, but not taco seasoning. I have done that and it works fine though. I do not put in olives or lettuce, but sometimes add a guacamole layer. If I have green onions, they go in, but I usually just use red onions. I always add some jalapenos over the cheese, and I usually use a reduced fat Mexican cheese blend from the cheese aisle. Nobody ever suspects it's all low fat, and it's ALWAYS gone quickly!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good but it makes A TON of dip. If you're setting this out for a small group with other appetizers, this is way too much dip. It's essentially a casserole in a 9x13. You could cut the recipe in half and have plenty. I added a pound of browned ground beef and wouldn't dispense with it. I also baked mine with lots of Mexican blend cheese on top. I can't imagine this would be as satisfying cold. I didn't use salsa-- just a can of Rotel tomatoes with peppers, undrained. I didn't use lettuce either. I added black beans. Maybe having small bowls of con queso, guacamole & taco sauce on the side for serving with this dip would work. Decent dip recipe.

text:
Good recipe but didn't listen to other reviewers and followed the recipe but whole package of taco seasoning is too much!  I love taco seasoning so much I could probably eat it with a spoon, but in this recipe it overwhelms all the other flavors.  Next time will use half pack.  Also added guac to mine, in this order from bottom: bean/taco season; guac, cream cheese/sour cream; chunky salsa (drained); lettuce; cheese.  Skipped the green peppers and onions as wasn't sure if my guests liked them, but will add for myself next time.  I used shredded iceberg lettuce and it held up perfectly, even the next day still looked crisp & fresh.

text:
Easy to prepare (20 minutes) and yummy.  Made a 5-layer variation (bottom to top): 1 14-oz can low sodium baked beans, mixture of 16-oz low-fat sour cream + 8-oz low-fat cream cheese + 3/4 package taco mix, 3 diced fresh tomatoes, 1 small jar medium-spicy salsa, lots of shredded mozza and cheddar cheese.  Baked at 350 for 30 minutes, and it was so good.  Everyone loved it - great with multi-grain nacho chips!

This was pretty good. It made a lot (2 dishes for me), which was perfect, but ended up being a little runny for my tastes. That might come down to what kind of salsa you use, so if you have a runnier salsa, you might want to drain it a bit first, or pare back to half the amount.

text:
Good recipe..I changed a few things to my taste.  I mixed refried beans and hamburger together with a packet and a half of taco seasoning.  Then I layered the meat mixture, sour cream, lettuce, olives, a can of RoTel tomoates and cilantro, cheese, and green onions.  Then I drizzled taco sauce on top. It was a big hit at the New Year's Eve Party!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent guide for seven layer dip.  As always, I made several changes.  I started with vegetarian refried beans.  Then added a fat free sour cream/cream cheese mixture.  Layer 3 was 2 pureed avocados.  Layer 4 was 3 large chopped tomatoes.  Layer 5 was chopped chili and jalapeno peppers and 1/2 large yellow onion.  Layer 6 was torn up iceburg lettuce.  And finally, layer 7 was shredded pepper jack cheese.  The dip was a big hit at a recent BBQ!

Display Name:
Fly by Light
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/269154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great stuff and quick to prepare for a party.  I had no leftovers.  Tips:  traditional beans (w/ lard), lightened up sour cream and cream cheese (used Neufchatel), allrecipes taco seasoning ( 1 1/2 tablespoons), Kroger premium lime salsa, no olives.  Lettuce and peppers were not critical, but they lighten up all the protein.  I went light on cheese and lettuce.  I used a round casserole, which was easy to transport, but 11x17 or two smaller flat pans  would have been more "dipping friendly".  Save some scallions to garnish top if you don't use olives.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1123398.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed this up a bit as my husband is allergic to cream cheese (weird, I know!). I replaced the cream cheese with drained cottage cheese. I processed the cottage cheese and the sour cream together till smooth and continued with the recipe as usual. It was a HUGE hit and my hubby was able to enjoy it too! Next time though, I am going to try ricotta instead (the cottage cheese was still a bit too runny for my liking) or an actual cream cheese substitute. Also, I am going to use two cans of refried beans on the bottom layer as I didn't find it thick enough with just one. Be sure to use a 9x13 pan, this recipe makes a lot of delicious dip!! Thanks, Sue!

text:
I made my own black bean dip- 2 cans of black beans for the bottom. I forgot to buy Green Peppers. It still came out good. I put it on a large round glass platter. A good trick I learned was to take 5 or 6 papers towels , still attached and fold them up to make a band. Wrap that around the edge if you are refrigerating overnight. The first time I made it juices ran out all over my fridge. This time I came up with the band and there was no mess.

The sour cream/cream cheese combo are delicious together and the refried beans are very flavorful with the seasoning. I've made this before and was called yesterday to bring it to another family function.  I left out the green peppers just because I don't like them raw, but otherwise made just to recipe. text:
This was very good I did mine a bit diffrent. I used a 9x13 pan.Left out green pepper, added plain mashed avacado layer,a taco sauce layer & I did about 3/4c sour cream with 1/2 bar of cream cheese mixed with the taco season & used a can of rotel diced tomatoes & green chilis(drained) in place of salsa since I added about 1/4c picante sauce directly in the beans to make them smooth I also used double the beans this called for I think was 30oz can. & I did top it with lettuce I would not leave it out I used the ready shred lettuce & it did not wilt & was still good the next day.So mine went bean mixture,avacado,sour cream mixture,taco sauce,rotel tomato green chilis,cheese, lettuce,olives,green onions.Delicious I will make it again!!! Best served at room temperature I think!:)

None
text:
This was fantastic!  I made as directed except I did add 1-2 spoonfuls of the salsa to the beans to thin them out for easier dipping(as suggested by another reviewer.)  I also didn't use fresh tomatoes because they looked pitiful at my store.  I used red bell pepper instead because I already had it.  I thought that the bell pepper and taco seasoning in the beans made this better than other versions of this that I have made.  Almost needless to say, but there were NO leftovers at the end of the meeting (with lots of mostly full dishes left on the table.)  I also found the 9x13 to be a good size.  I might try adding an an extra half can of beans next time as some others have suggested as the bean layer was thinner than the cream cheese/sour cream layer.

text:
I LOVE this recipe as a base, but I made a fair amount of changes. I left out the chopped tomato, pepper, scallions and lettuce, along w/ the cream cheese. My dish ended up like this: Layer 1, taco seasoning mix and refried beans; Layer 2, sour cream; Layer 3, guacamole; Layer 4, salsa; Layer 5, taco sauce; Layer 6, cheddar cheese. The taco sauce and guac really added some spice and kick. This was a big hit and I'll definitely make it again!!

text:
I personally would have given this 2 stars, my husband 4, so I met in the middle with 3. I thought it was bland and boring, definitely missing something. I'm not a huge fan of cold dips, so this may have influenced my opinion. I think if I ever tried this dip again, I would double the beans, mix the taco seasoning with the sour cream and cream cheese instead of the beans, leave out the lettuce, and add some beef. The salsa (I used a jar of homemade-style) made this dip very runny. If you're looking for a good bean dip, try Ranch Bean Dip on this site. It's wonderful.

text:
My sister has always made some variation of the basic layer dip recipe, but I swear by this website so I looked here first.  I substituted organic black refried beans with roasted red jalapenos for the standard beans, black bean and corn salsa, 3 roma tomatoes instead of one large tomato, yellow pepper instead of green for more color, and 4-cheese Mexican blend instead of cheddar.  I took it to my boyfriend's dad's birthday dinner and everyone loved it! It was a small gathering, but his brother-in-law even claimed the leftovers (half a 9x13) to take home.  This will be a new favorite here.

Some things I just want to keep for myself and this recipe is definetely one of them!

This was an AMAZING hit at a pot luck for work.  I browned 1 lb. of hamburger and mixed in the refried beans, added guacamole on top of the sour cream/cream cheese mixture, and left out the lettuce and tomatoes, because i didn't want it to get wilty and soggy and there was a lot of tomatoe chunks in the salsa.  it was a  HUGE hit.  I highly recommend this recipe! I will be using many many more times in the future.

text:
Wow this is delicious for breakfast, lunch and dinner! haha! Just kidding but I served this today as an appetizer for my guests at my daughters 1st bday party and everyone loved it there was hardly any left over! I added guacamole to it and I made that by adding just a packet of guacamole seasoning mix stuff and I added the taco seasoning to the cream cheese/sour cream mix in which i didn't add that much cream cheese or sour cream. I felt only half of each that was listed was enough! thanks for the great recipe :) I can't wait to eat the left overs! I forgot to add that this dish is GREAT served cold! After I put it together I put it in the fridge for about 15 minutes and then served it but I put the leftovers away for a few hours and then snacked on it later and it was even better colder. :)

text:
There really isn't much to say that hasn't been said before. This really is a great recipe! Apart from topping it with sliced jalapenos, I made it exactly as directed, and it was great! (Personally, I like adding the diced tomatoes in addition to the salsa. It just gives it an extra fresh, zingy flavor.) The second time I made it, I used El Paso refried beans, and they were much MUCH saltier than the Meijer brand beans I used the first time. Despite this, it still got gobbled up at Husband's work's potluck. I think this is going to be my staple potluck contribution. Thanks!

text:
I should have used only 1/2 the taco seasoning because the beans were way salty.  Also, I wouldn't use a platter because this dish spreads.  The dish you put it in needs to have some depth.  The lettuce is a little awkward to dip into with a chip so either tear the lettuce into smaller pieces or omit them.  We did eat a lot of this dip, although next time I would make some major tweeks in the recipe.

text:
This is very good!  This recipe was one of the dishes I served at a small party (30 people) and very little was left over, which is always a good sign!  After washing lettuce, be sure that as  much water is removed as possible.  Same goes for the olives.  You may want to use a "thick" salsa that isn't too liquidy, as the dip can get a little watery.  So, next time I will be sure that all water is removed from lettuce and olives and use a thicker salsa.  Otherwise, excellent.  I will make it again.

Ok, ok.  Just like some of you I thought 7 layer dip was pretty boring.  But I was asked to make 7 layer dip to bring to a party and I chose this recipe.  IT IS FABULOUS!  It got RAVE reviews.  The green pepper really adds to a great flavor.  I omitted the lettuce becuase lettuce can get pretty soggy if left out at room temp.  EVERYONE LOVED THIS!  It was the first appitizer to be completely eaten out of 7 appetizers that were out on the table.  I will be making this very often.  Thanks for a great recipe!!!!!

country:
None
text:
I had to dig to find the recipe again, and glad I did!  Last time we made it, it was inhaled, and I've had more requests... 
One note - someone said they replaced the refried beans with hamburger.  The only caution I would use there is if you think the dip will be sitting out for more than two hours, you might want to re-think the meat.  It doesn't hurt the dairy mixture as much, due to the other ingredients mixed in, but meat could be prone to more bacteria. 

Of course, this is an unnecessary warning, since it is doubtful this dip will last long enough to worry about refrigerating it!  Ha!

Make it, buy plenty of tortilla chips and let them dig in....

Postively Terrific! I've made this twice now, doubled the recipe to make two big plates. The company gobbled it up each time! Both Plates! I think one thing that makes it really great is the tacco spices (pre-packaged) mixed with the re-fried beans. I'd had a recipe previous that didn't call for the peppers or green onions. My group seems to very much enjoy their addition. Of course you can leave out any little topping you don't like, example many don't want the peppers or maybe the olives to top it with. Whatever you like you and adjust. LOVE IT!
