text:
This is a very good basic recipe that can easily be tweaked to your own liking. 
One reviewer stated that cream cheese doesn't belong in this dip. Well, I suppose not if you're trying to make authentic Mexican, but I think the creaminess is what makes this dish. It balances nicely with the robust flavor of the taco seasoning, tomatoes, onions, and olives.
Next time I will add a layer of guacamole.
This would go nicely with black beans and corn also.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I brought this to a drama potluck as well as just ate it at home and everyone loved it and kept going back for more! I personally didn't put the olives on because I don't like them. The first time I made it, I didn't put very much lettuce on because I was worried about it wilting, but I found it too cheesy. The second time I made it, I put on the whole head of lettuce (or, most of it) and it was much better and didn't even wilt! I also discovered that it doesn't really matter what type of bell pepper you use because no one can tell the difference anyways, so just use whatever you have on hand! Definitely recommend trying it!

I made some changes - I omitted the peppers - I didn't think the peppers were a right taste - I use two cans of refried beans as the base in a 11 x 13 - I mix the taco mix in the sour cream and cream cheese mix for the next layer, I then add a layer of shredded chicken which I add to the salsa for a thicker mix, then I add the lettuce, green onions, tomatoes, cheese and olives....everyone likes it that way.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My version is a bit different, ditch the cream cheese, replace with homemade (store bought in a pinch, but make it a good brand), guacamole.  Skip the green pepper and lettuce.  Use coarsely chopped cilantro.  I make 2 pans one with no onions or cilantro and the other one with lots of onions and cilantro.  Both are always one of the first dishes to go quickly, along with my grilled shrimp cocktail and deviled eggs . . . Have been making for 35+ years and people still love it.  If you want to make extra special, after the refried bean layer, use pulled pork or ground beef cooked with fajita seasonings.  Enjoy!

userID:
14394409
Display Name:
ChefDad
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
215
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1984221.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Big hit!!! I made this for the Super Bowl we had about 8 guests. I made BBQ to go along with it. Everyone pounced on this dip and left most of the BBQ... it was gone in a bling of an eye. I served with Tostitos Scoops tortilla chips and Frito's Scoops.  I followed close to main recipe but used a few suggestions from others. Made it in a 9x13 Pyrex glass baking pan and used an electric hand mixer for mixing. I used 2 cans of black bean refried beans and mixed with a package of Taco Seasoning and a couple of TBS's of Kroger brand chunky salsa drained - this made it a little softer so not to break the chips when dipping. Second layer was cream cheese and sour cream mixed with a half packet of Taco Seasoning. Next layer was Chunky Salsa and I drained in strainer to get all the watery liquid out this is a must so that your dip doesn't get watery. Next layer was guacamole I made from recipe on this site (Bob Cody). Next layer was chopped green pepper, I omitted the green onion because I had a red onion and garlic in the guacamole. Next layer was a can of drained diced tomatoes with green chilies. Next layer was shredded cabbage, I used instead of lettuce because it won't wilt as fast, I bought a bag of coleslaw mix and it really worked out well. Next layer was shredded sharp cheddar cheese then topped off with a small can of sliced black olives. I baked on 350 for 30 minutes and when it came out MAN everyone stood around with there eyes bugged out!!! My son woke up next day and ask

Rating:
5

I used 2 cans of refried beans, not one. I used romaine, and not iceberg lettuce. Also, please not the refried beans are NOT heated. This is a cold dish. It stays fresh over night, then. :) YUMMM!

I am rating this although I did not actually get to taste it. It was the first item finished off at my latest work potluck and I didn't even get any! I added a little salsa to the bean mix and then I topped the beans with the remaining salsa (pretty thick). I hoped this would solve any mess issues people have described. I had to use a food processor for the sour cream and cream cheese, in order to make it smooth. Then I topped it with cheese, lettuce, more cheese, the green onions, tomatos and black olives. From what I saw there didn't seem to be much of a mess and there was no time for any lettuce wilting. I should have made double.

userID:
14649741
Display Name:
Rebecca Saxon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

4

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5091692.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dip is freaking awesome!!!!! I honestly couldn't have asked for a better 7 layer dip. It's a great base recipe, and I did make a few changes. I took out the lettuce, green peppers and I tomato's. I felt the dish didn't need it. However I did add in guacamole and it was awesome!! Here were my layers (from bottom to top): 1.5 cans of refried beans mixed with taco seasoning, sour cream/cream cheese mix, guacamole, chunky salsa (that's been drained, otherwise it will be a runny mess), a bunch of finely shredded cheese, olives and green onions. It was a huge hit at the BBQ! I have to admit, I'm glad there was a little left over so I could pig out on it when I got home. I also used Tostitos Scoops for the chips, since its a pretty thick dip. Enjoy! And try not to eat too much!

text:
This is a good base recipe.  Had to make changes since many of the ingredients just don't work for me:
1 LB of lean turkey with the taco seasoning,
8oz sour cream mixed with 4oz cream cheese,
16oz salsa - drained,
1 bell pepper ( any color ),
2 c shredded cheese.
I bring large size Frito chips.  This is always a hit wherever I go.

country:

text:
I made this recipe, as written, early Christmas morning for a family get together later that evening. Everyone has something in here that they say they "don't like". I'm over trying to please everyone, so I bought 2 red oval serving dishes from the dollar store and made/served the dip in one and put Mission Brand Tortilla Strips in the other. The dip ingredients were layered and placed in such a way that everyone could serve themselves what they liked and not have to include what they didn't like. Everyone loved the dish. I loved two things:  easy breezy recipe to make and they could keep my serving dishes. UPDATE: This recipe has been requested again for this year's Christmas family get together and I am preparing it in exactly the same way.

My husband and I loved it so much, we didn't expect it to be that much... We ate half of it for couple days & we had to throw out rest since it was going bad... I thought it should have had guacamole, but I made it by the directions. Next time, I'll leave out the lettuce and green pepper, and add guac like another reviewer suggested. YUM all the same! (Great for my super bowl party)

text:
This dip is a huge hit especially in the spring and summer months. I keep it a bit healthier by using Fat Free Refried beans, low sodium Taco seasoning, reduced fat shreeded cheddar, and 1/3 less fat cream cheese. It still tastes AWESOME - also this is great for anyone that is on a low carb diet, just skip the chips and dip with fresh sliced peppers or grape tomatoes!   The fact that it is a cold dip makes it so refreshing on a hot day. I brought to a party once and everyone demaned the recipe, it has been made by various friends of mine too!

This was so good.  I used jalapeno refried beans and hot taco seasoning just to spice it up, I popped the beans in the microwave just to make them easier to spread.  A 9x13 pyrex dish worked perfectly for me.  I made the recipe exactly as written except for the bell pepper, I definitely would NOT omit the lettuce like some reviewers...it gives it a nice crunch and I had no problem with wilting but then again it didn't sit around very long:)  It was a perfect Superbowl snack, thanks for sharing!

text:
This is always a winner!  Try this delicious, but not exactly calorie-free, variation:  take a tube (two for large servings) of crescent rolls and roll them out like a pizza dough.  They will spread as you roll them and become seamless. Cook it until it's golden brown.  375 degrees, maybe 15 minutes.  Then make the dip the way you like it right there on the crescent roll pizza.  Good stuff!

This is an amazing taco dip recipe.  I make this for my pot luck luncheons at work and everyone asks "who made the taco dip??"  It is so delicious.  The beans mixed with the taco seasoning and the sour cream mixed with the cream cheese are what really makes this great. I usually double all of the ingredients because everyone loves it and always wants seconds.

text:
If you really want to do something different with 7 layer dip, spread the bean mix and a layer of queso dip (old el paso has one ... there are others.. same sized jar as salsa) to the bottom of the pan. Stick that in the oven at 350 until it bubbles. add a layer of salsa, then sour cream then guac. i just add some diced red onions and diced tomatoes... grated cheese and shredded lettuce on top... mmmmm mmmmm!

text:
I wanted to make a taco dip after finding some at the local grocery store that was quite good, but when we went back for another one it was so runny.  This recipe was the first one I found and after reading the recipe and reviews I decided to make it for dinner.  Unfortunately my hubby didn't care for it, but my son loved it.  We used it as a baked potato topping, yum yum!  I made homemade guacamole to layer between the beans (which I heated in a pan before mixing in the taco seasoning) and the sour cream/cream cheese mixture.  That is because my son can't have the dairy so I figured the guacamole would be a nice creamy substitute on his side of the dip.  His side of the dip also had goat cheese.  Other than that, there were no substitutions made, except I forgot the lettuce.  Thank you for this yummy dip, we will be taking it to our next fellowship meal at church!!

I make this all the time but I make it a little different. I mix the cream cheese w/ 2 Tablespoons taco seasoning mix and make that my first layer. But as for everything else I do the same as whats printed on this recipe.

text:
I love taco dips, but find some of them too spicy for my taste. With this recipe I was able to alter it to my taste by using mild salsa and mild taco seasoning. I also added a layer of ground beef over the refried beans that I made with taco seasoning as well. My boyfriend and I also like soft tacos, so I make the "dip" with the ground beef and then serve it with warm flour tortillas and spanish rice. That way everyone can put as much stuff in their soft tacos without 40 plates on the table.

text:
This was the best taco dip ever, and it was a huge hit at my families annual wreath making party.  The only changes I made was I excluded the lettuce cause it can get soggy, and the peppers and onion (only because I didn't have any) and I added guacamole. The only thing I would change is drain the salsa a little cause it can get watery over a long period of time.

text:
I make a layer dip similar to this and it is always a favorite at parties! I use a small cookie sheet and layer these ingredients.  1 can refried beans 1/2 lg container sour cream mixed with 1/2 packet taco seasoning quacamole I make with 3-4 avacados mixed in the food processor with a couple TBS Olive oil and a few squeezes of lime juice salsa (black bean/corn, cilantro, any kind you like..) 1 can drained rinsed black beans if not in salsa 1/2-1 packet mexican shredded cheese  sliced olives, diced tomatoes, lettuce to garnish I have used tried mixing the cream cheese like this recipe calls for but I couldn't tell the difference with it included.

country:

text:
We tried this for the Super Bowl and it was very good! I think next time I would use half of the taco seasoning, simply because I like the taste of the beans more. Instead of the tomato and lettuce layers I did LuvAnn's fresh guacamole. While i completely LOVE this guac it doesn't stay good on the dip for long. I wouldn't make it in hope of a snack for several days, it is definitely meant to be eaten right away. It fits into a 9x13 dish very well, but you could half it into an 8x8 I think. I put more beans in it because the amount of beans was really small to the amount of cream cheese and sour cream. They were not even close amounts. Other then that this dip was a huge hit. People ate so much that they weren't hungry for the pizza later!

text:
I made this a little while ago. It was pretty good, but a little watery. I skipped the pepper and tomato since we didn't have any and I used a can of Rotel tomatoes with green chillies and drained it, but I guess not well enough. I also skipped the olives. It was yummy warm or cold. Will probably try again for another party! UPDATE!! I tried this with just the taco seasoning, beans, cream cheese, sour cream, and cheddar cheese and it's WAY better!  People at the party I went to loved it much better this way. I honestly dont care if its not as healthy. Parties aren't supposed to be healthy--people eat what they want!

userID:
627214
Display Name:
CYNDIDH
isPro:

106

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'd never had a taco dip before, and this one was really tasty. I followed the package instructions on the taco seasoning and cooked hamburger meat with it. I couldn't find refried beans, so I just used a can of pinto beans mashed up. I mixed the mashed up beans with the taco-seasoned hamburger meat. That was my bottom later. On top of that, I added cheese, then the sour cream and cream cheese mixture. Then I added the green onions and salsa (which I strained to remove most of the juice) and the chopped tomatoes. I left out the green peppers because the salsa I used already had green peppers in it. I also left out the black olives just because I don't like them. I thought I would like this dip better warm, so I put it in a 350 degree oven just until the dip was warm/cheese was melted. Then I added finely chopped lettuce to the top. It was quite delicious. I heated some up the next day just until it was warm, and I thought it was still quite tasty. Yes, the pieces of lettuce were warm, but the pieces were so small and the whole thing was so tasty that I didn't really notice that I was eating warm lettuce. I notice a lot of reviewers have left the lettuce off over wilting concerns... but I think the lettuce added a lot to this dip. Who cares if it becomes wilted? Once your guests taste this dip, I highly doubt anyone is going to be worried about the appearance of the lettuce.

text:
This is absolutely fabulous.  I made it as described, aside from using low fat cream cheese and low fat sour cream.  I also skipped the green peppers because they are not my favourite.  I had been concerned that the lettuce would get soggy but based on some of the positive comments about the lettuce, I kept it in. I'm glad I did!  It was yummy and made it a bit different. 

It makes a huge amount and I did have the thought that since I had leftovers, maybe I shouldn't have put the lettuce in it, as now it would be soggy and the leftovers might go to waste.  I opened it up this afternoon (the party was yesterday) to see if I could pick out the lettuce and still enjoy the dip.

To my surprise the lettuce is STILL crispy, not in the slightest bit soggy.  I had made a point to spin it in the salad spinner first before putting it on the dip though I thought surely it would absorb the moisture from the salsa.  it didn't, the dip is great even as leftovers, had some for lunch without chips - just on a fork.  Yum!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was a definite winner with the crowd! I did some changes as others did. Here is my version;

Recipe Alterations:
 
Omitted: tomato, olives, lettuce, bell pepper
 
1). brown 1lb hamburger - mix in refried beans and half of the taco seasoning mix
2), add a layer of guacamole
3). used mango/pineapple salsa (really can use whatever flavor you want)
4). added a layer of mild chopped chilis (sm can)
5). instead of chopped tomato used a can of Rotel chopped tomatos and chilis
6). mixed the other half of the taco seasoning mix with the cream cheese and sour cream
7). used green onions as garnish on top of the cheese
 
Order of layers starting with:
 
burger/beans
guacamole
sour cream/cream cheese
chilis
salsa
cheddar
green onions

text:
I make a recipe very similar to this every year, it is a huge hit.  
I place a layer of refried beans on the bottom of a deep serving platter, than I mix a packet of taco seasoning mix into a tub of sour cream and that is the next layer, followed by lettuce, tomato, shredded mexican cheese, scallions and than diced black olives.  Everyone loves this dip!!!

text:
I made this last night for my New Year's Eve party, and it was a hit!  I made it in a 7x11 dish, and used 8 oz sour cream and about 6 oz of whipped cream cheese.  Then I spread the salsa over that, sprinkled on chopped tomato and lettuce, and then topped with colby jack cheese, and drizzled a generous helping of catalina dressing over the top, a la "taco salad".  I served it with Tostitos Scoops and everyone loved it!  Thanks for the keeper recipe!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2061336.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I served this taco dip at a football game get together at our home, and got wonderful reviews! However, I did make several changes. I added store-bought guacamole in the center layer (before I topped the salsa on) and added chopped cilantro and some jalapeno peppers on the  layer after the diced tomatoes (instead of green peppers). I thought that really "salsa-sized" the taco dip and the cilantro added a yummy tang to the dip. Make sure you use thick/chunky salsa. I used homemade salsa with homegrown tomatoes and it was a little watery than store-bought, so there was a little pool of water in the middle of the dip. That was my own doing though, so I still think this recipe is a real keeper!
Review:
Rating:
5

This is good, looks pretty, and was eaten up by the group of men and women in our card group.  I used low fat cheese, sour cream and cream cheese and no one was any the wiser. I thought it needed more kick and would increase the mexican spices for more flavor next time.  More chile powder, onion powder, cumin. I arranged giant sliced black olives on the top as the finish, and it really did look quite nice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WONDERFUL!  I made this for my boyfriend's sake because he LOVES seven layer dip, but I think I ended up eating more of it than he did!  I just can't stop eating it!  The taco seasoning packet I had was 1.25 ounces which I think ended up being a little bit too much...so I think next time I will look for the suggested 1-ounce packet.  I used fat free refried beans, fat free cream cheese, and light sour cream.  I LOVED the cream cheese/sour cream mixture...I normally HATE sour cream, but this combo made it edible for me!  I added a layer of guacamole after the sour cream layer (Easy Guacamole from this site) and omitted the bell pepper and lettuce.  I only used half of the recommended amount of sour cream & cream cheese, as well as salsa (I originally planned on only making half recipe...so that's what I bought ingredients for) and will probably continue to do this in the future.  Thanks for the awesome recipe!!

text:
Very good and simple appetizer Sue...not to mention popular.  To accomidate others we left out the cream cheese, sour cream and green peppers.  These are normally "personal preference" items and don't hurt the overall out come of the finished product if left out.  We spread guacamole on top and it turned out great.
